headline.main: A Life Lesson Learned in Medical School

docs.abstract: A patient who produces a surprising response to a time-tested question teaches a valuable lesson: It can be hard to distinguish truth from a perfectly good answer.
docs.lead_paragraph: It was in my second year of medical school that I learned one of the most important lessons of my career: That it can be hard to distinguish truth from a perfectly good answer. Certainty was what I craved the most back then, poised as I was on the threshold of my medical career. But my first patient would cure me of certainty forever.
docs.snippet: A patient who produces a surprising response to a time-tested question teaches a valuable lesson: It can be hard to distinguish truth from a perfectly good answer.

docs.abstract: Caregiving obligations are deeply felt in many Hispanic families, but tradition is running up against harsh modern realities, experts say.
docs.lead_paragraph: Fabiola Santiago lives in the Miami suburbs, two miles from her 81-year-old mother and 87-year-old father, whom she looks after. As the single mother of three grown daughters, she might live in the city or in Miami Beach if she had no family responsibilities -- but to her, that's like saying she'd fly if she woke up tomorrow with wings. It's a fantasy.
docs.snippet: Caregiving obligations are deeply felt in many Hispanic families, but tradition is running up against harsh modern realities, experts say.

headline.main: A Possible Silver Lining for Hot Flashes

docs.abstract: Women with the most severe hot flashes and other symptoms of menopause were at lower risk for breast cancer, one study found.
docs.lead_paragraph: Do hot flashes have a silver lining?
docs.snippet: Women with the most severe hot flashes and other symptoms of menopause were at lower risk for breast cancer, one study found.

headline.main: Central Heating May Be Making Us Fat

docs.abstract: Turning down the thermostat may help us lose weight, some scientists say.
docs.lead_paragraph: Americans like to crank up the heat in the winter -- and some scientists think it's making us fat. Turn down the thermostat, they say, and you might lose a few pounds.
docs.snippet: Turning down the thermostat may help us lose weight, some scientists say.

docs.abstract: A new National Academy of Sciences report names smoking and lack of universal health insurance. Obesity and inequality are also mentioned as possibilities.
docs.lead_paragraph: The National Academy of Sciences has just released a fascinating report on life expectancy in rich countries around the world. The researchers who wrote the report -- public-health experts, demographers, economists and others, from around the world -- have tried to figure out why Americans don't live as long as people in many other countries.
docs.snippet: A new National Academy of Sciences report names smoking and lack of universal health insurance. Obesity and inequality are also mentioned as possibilities.
